videos.title: 6 Times Table Song | Skip Counting by 6 | Multiplication Song
videos.description:
Our mission? Make math fun, engaging, and oh-so-easy for both you & your students.  Our library of lesson materials is not only super-affordable but is also FREE to try out at http://numberock.com/letsrockmath.

Multiples of Six Song History:
In the neon-lit heart of KidzVibe Night Club, just a few meters beyond the monkey bars,   DJ Six-Tables used to spin magic... well he did until it was time for the 2nd and 3rd Grade party-goers to head to bed at 8 O'clock. His turntables twisted out secrets of sixes for all the kids to lear, multiples radiated through the air like they tend to do in that environment. We've all been there and we know how it feels.

The kids danced in those times, and boy did they ever dance.  They danced like there was no school tomorrow - and probably because there WAS no school tomorrow.  It was Arbor Day, and that town loved its trees even more than Clay Aiken, beloved former American idol Winner, so everybody got the day off - and the proceeding day as well.  

In those days of unrestricted freedom, you could hear a chant emerge as far away as Numberock St.  6! 12! 18! 24!  Laughter would erupt as DJ Six-Tables dropped a beat, only to catch the audience off guard with a math joke, “Why did the number 6 feel sad? And the answer? Because 7, ate, 9!” The room erupted, theories of humor have been debated for centuries, but that joke would eventually force humor scientists to reevaluate everything they had ever known.  The kids understood, and that was all that mattered.

And in that kaleidoscope of giggles, math became cool again. DJ Six Tables will remain a legend! He was the ultimate remix in human form: part educator, part musical maestro, and 100% soul.

videos.title: Angles Song | Acute, Obtuse, & Right Angles | 3rd & 4th Grade
videos.description:
Our mission? Make math fun, engaging, and oh-so-easy for both you & your students.  Our library of lesson materials is not only super-affordable but is also FREE to try out at http://numberock.com/letsrockmath.

Video Summary:
Earl, our trusty pizza delivery guy, insists that if you toss a whole pizza at the wall, it’ll stick. So we decided to put his theory to the test by inviting him over and it ended up turning into this Angles Video. 

Speaking of angles - isn't that the whole point of the video?! - to teach kids about different types of angles and how to measure them?  I'm not really sure anymore.

Regarding angles, we'll make sure to ask the important questions, like:  

Which type of angle is the cutest? 
I think right angles, personally. They try to act all perfect and 90, but who is buying that?!

OK, Quick Update: Apparently that question is supposed to be a joke, and that the answer should be, "A CUTE ANGLE".  I give this joke a single HA. How many HA's do you give it?

And, which angle looks like the antlers on the head of a FULL-GROWN moose?! 
Well, clearly that would be the obtuse angle.  We prove this with absolute certainty if you watch the actual video.  It's probably the last time we'll have a moose in a video.  You wouldn't believe what it costs to rent a moose for an hour these days.

Now let's return back to watching the video so we can discover our own personal answers to these questions.  And all kidding aside, it's time to put on your serious face on now.  And let's learn a thing or two, shall we?!

videos.title: Metric System For Kids: Explained Through Song
videos.description:
🍎  You're cordially invited to come check out our growing library of award-winning math video animations at https://www.numberock.com  🍎

Thank you for watching our Metric System For Kids Song.  

 »»-------------¤-------------««»»-------------¤-------------««

Q. What makes up the Metric system?
A. The metric system is made up of 7 units which are Metre for length, Kilogramme for weight, second for time, Ampere for electrical current, Kelvin for temperature, Mole for amount of substance and finally Candele for luminous intensity. 

Q. What grade levels do this video target?
A. This video targets learning standards in 3rd Grade and 5th Grade.  This video also targets standards in the UK from KS4 (Year 4-6).

Q. Where did you guys come from?
A. Numberock is a project that I, Mr. Hehn, began as a 5th Grade math teacher of 7 years.  It came together after years of experimenting with my lessons trying to figure out the best way to help my students retain the math concepts they were learning.  

Q. Does Numberock drive real results in the classroom?
A. I knew I found the secret sauce when not only were my students retaining the concepts longer, they were singing the songs outside of the classroom during recess and at home with their parents during dinnertime.  The songs were so catchy, my students couldn't get the math songs out of their head!  

During testing, I often found my students humming the melodies in order to jostle their memory of a rule or problem solving process.  As we've all experienced, there is something about the power of music that allows us to retain information easier and for longer periods of time.  Without getting into the finer details of multi-sensory learning and how it often helps the students who most need the help, the power of a catchy song is hard to deny.

Q. I love your songs.  Where can I experience more of what NUMBEROCK has to offer?

We have additional teaching resources that are always expanding over at https://www.numberock.com.  For the low price of $4.95/month, premium members gain access to video-aligned activities like worksheets, printable posters/anchor charts, task cards, self-graded assessments, games, and more.  

Coming Soon:
1. Self-Graded Assessments | These will soon be available for every Common Core and TEKS standard from 2nd-6th Grade so you'll be able to track and monitor student progress while your students complete standards-aligned quizzes that are integrated with the NUMBEROCK video they just watched.

2. Number Notes | Were currently working on creating exercises where students will be able to take notes artistically on printable templates featuring characters from the videos.  

Research has shown that this will help to integrate their artistic side side of the student's brain with the mathematical side of their brain which helps with long-term memory retention.  Our own research has shown us that teacher's who use start using these templates love them!  It seems to be a natural fit as we move beyond our unique auditory learning tools into visual learning tools, that when used in concert, cater to the different types of learners that you teach everyday.

🍎 Hope to see you at https://numberock.com! 🍎

videos.title: 3D Shapes Song for Kids
videos.description:
Our mission? Make math fun, engaging, and oh-so-easy for both you & your students.  Our library of lesson materials is not only super-affordable but is also FREE to try out at http://numberock.com/letsrockmath.

Video Summary:
“3-D shapes! You know, those colorful things that make you feel like a three-dimensional kid again. Let’s explore a few of them, as seen in the video above, and address the burning question: Do these shapes serve any purpose, or can we simply banish them from our lives altogether?” 😄🔍

Cylinders: Picture it: you’re sipping your fizzy drink, and there it is—a cylinder, just hanging out, being all cylindrical. Two circular bases, congruent and parallel faces. It’s like they’re saying, “Hey, I’m practical! Store your soup or your soda in me!” 🥫🥤

Cones: You spot these bad boys in construction zones, right next to the orange cones that scream, “I was born this way!” But wait, there’s more! Cones can be cream holders. 🍦🚧 Wherever you see a circular base which has points that meet at the tippy-top, just like a party hat, you pretty much know what you have to deal with that that point. It’s like they’re saying, “I’m versatile! I can hold traffic or sprinkles!” 🎉

Pyramids: Ancient Aztecs and Egyptians were basically the original architects. They whipped up pyramids like it was a Tuesday afternoon.🔺 Mayans joined the party too and built a few! These babies have a polygon base (think triangles, squares, or pentagons) and triangular faces that meet in once place. There are many theories about why pyramids were built, but I most Egyptologists now believe that they just wanted to make a really cool 3D Shapes video but forgot to invent cameras.

Prisms: Rectangular prisms? They’re like rooms or the box my cute little Cabbage Patch Doll I named "Pink Baby Hardhead Rosie" was delivered in. Triangular prisms? Doghouse roof vibes, for real. Basically, any polygon with edges joining at the vertices can be a prism. It’s like they’re saying, “You don't knoooow me! I can be what I wanna be!” 

Spheres: These are the rock stars of the 3-D world. No base, no boundaries—just pure roundness. Planets? Yep, they’re perfectly round spheres. You guessed it—sphere! Spheres are basically nature's way of saying, "My spheres are bigger than your spheres."🌎🎱

So there you have it, folks. 3-D shapes: the unsung heroes of geometry. They’re not just math; they’re life. Next time you see a soda can, give it a nod, then check to see if it loaded with high fructose corn syrup. Gotta watch those sugar levels, sphere-iously.

The millimeter (mm) - that tiny speck of measurement units, it's akin to the minuscule grain of sand that clings to your shoe after a beach adventure. 

The centimeter (cm) - Imagine a staple.  It's about that size.  It’s like the universe decided, “Let’s measure things with office supplies!”

The meter (m) - It's about the distance from most door handles to the floor.  Other items that measure about a meter long are baseball bats, guitars, and one meter long rulers made by reputable companies.

The kilometer (km) - This is about how long you'd make it if you were take a 10 minute walk along the beach, or if you were to walk 12 city blocks. 

Now get measuring!

videos.title: Area Model Multiplication Song | Multiplying with Partial Products
videos.description:
Our mission? Make math fun, engaging, and oh-so-easy for both you & your students.  Our library of lesson materials is not only super-affordable but is also FREE to try out at http://numberock.com/letsrockmath.

Video Summary:
In our captivating Area Model Multiplication video, join Farmer Maslow as he takes us on a delightful tour of his coastal farm. Against the backdrop of the sea, he plants his new crops, all while demonstrating how to multiply two-digit by two-digit numbers using the area model. This approach, also known as Partial Products Multiplication, provides a geometric perspective that deepens our understanding of multiplication mechanics.

Farmer Maslow, a lover of Reggae music, green beans, and mathematics, has found the perfect blend in his profession. His coastal patch of land near the sea offers him a comfortable life. While he rarely breaks into a full dance routine, he often sways to the rhythm, feet firmly planted—a fitting reflection of his grounded nature.

We asked Farmer Maslow to pause from his farm work and share a brief explanation of how the area model impacts his daily life. Here’s what he had to say:

“The area model is akin to laying out a grid for your multiplication problem. Each cell in the grid represents a partial product.  

So, let's say you want to multiply 23 by 45, you can just break it down into smaller chunks.  In this example those smaller chunks will be 20 × 40, 20 × 5, then 3 × 40, and finally 3 × 5. 

Now,  just, add up these more simple partial products to arrive at the final answer! 🌟 

You know, nn my farm, I don’t need none of 'dem fancy chemicals or fertilizers to grow the freshest green beans this side of Kingston - nope - just a notepad, a sturdy pen, and a bit of good luck from the weather. Now, I’m off to gaze at the ocean while swaying  gently from side to side. Lata, mon. Mi Gaan.”

Thanks  Farmer M!  And as for where he lives? Five points if you guessed it:  Hint: The way he signed up holds the clue.🌱🌊

Lastly, a heartfelt thank you to our viewers and to Farmer Maslow for contributing to this delightful Area Model Multiplication Song. Until the next song, keep rocking those math skills!
tags: area model multiplication 2 digit by 2 digit

videos.title: Coordinate Plane and Ordered Pairs Song | 1st Quadrant
videos.description:
Our mission? Make math fun, engaging, and oh-so-easy for both you & your students.  Our library of lesson materials is not only super-affordable but is also FREE to try out at http://numberock.com/letsrockmath.

Video Summary:
Two intrepid 12-year-olds—Jamal and Lily—embarked on a unique quest. Their mission? To decode an ancient treasure map that led to a secret cave mysteriously named "Super Lady". The catch? The secret location of the treasure was hidden on a map full of coordinates plotted on the coordinate plane, devoid of any additional clues.

Jamal, sporting his trusty headband, and Lily, armed with his-and-hers mini-geography handbooks tucked away in her boots, trudged through the jungle. The air smelled of freshly sharpened pencils—the ones they had carved from trees—and carried a faint hope of extra credit.

“Jamal,” panted Lily, “are we lost?”

“Not even a little bit,” replied Jamal, squinting at Lily’s map. “Just a little more. We’re so close, I can taste (9,4)."

Their coordinates led them to a cave—a cave so eerie that its opening bore fangs. Inside, Jamal’s torchlight flickered, revealing equations etched into the walls. Jamal nudged Lily. “Behold! The x-axis and y-axis!” It was the most beautiful coordinate system they had ever seen.

And there, the story pretty much ends. Jamal and Lily didn’t mind that the treasure chest held no gold; the mathematical knowledge they gained from their adventure was the true reward. Besides, they were more than content with the vintage phones and years’ worth of classic Super Lady comic books they discovered.

Lastly, a heartfelt thank you to our viewers and to Jamal and Lily for contributing to this whimsical Coordinate Plane Song. We’ll see you in the next video. Until then, keep rocking those math skills!

videos.title: Simplest Form Song: Simplifying Fractions
videos.description:
If you like Numberock videos, you are cordially invited to try out our growing library-of equally engaging digital and printable learning resources FREE for a month:http://numberock.com/letsrockmath.

Video Backstory:
Deep beneath the ocean waves, where sunlight barely reaches, lived a colossal creature named Godzilla. But this wasn’t the Godzilla you’ve seen in movies—this one had a peculiar obsession: unsimplified fractions!

You see, Godzilla’s scales were heavy with the weight of countless fractions that hadn’t yet been converted into simplest form. Each day, he patrolled the murky waters, chasing submarines that carried these burdened calculations. Their hulls were etched with shattered numerators and denominators, like battle scars from forgotten math wars.

The submarines darted through the briny underwater stew, their propellers churning. Inside, wide-eyed crew members clung to their calculators, desperate to simplify the fractions before Godzilla caught up. “Reduce! Reduce!” they whispered, dividing numerators and denominators by the same value. The goal: to make those fractions as light as a feather.

But was there hope on land? Oh yes! On the shores, numbers catapulted skyward. They shattered sacrificially into fragments for the betterment of fractions and all of fraction-kind — like fragile shards of previously larger unsimplified  numbers. Reduced, yes, but not defeated! For even in their simplest forms, while carried the scars of division, the echoes of lost wholes, they were happy.

And the children? They watched from cliffs, their eyes wide. They saw the surreal dance of numbers, the battle between Godzilla and the submarines. It was like a math-themed blockbuster movie, with fractions flying toward and over them like fireworks.

And in their final simplest form, those fractions whispered a universal truth: We’re all part of something bigger, like pieces of a grand puzzle.

So next time you see a simplest-form fraction, remember what they had to go through to become one. And know that even in the scariest of moments, there’s hope—a new beginning waiting to unfold.

And never forget that in order to simplify a fraction into simplest form, one needs to divide the numerator (the top number) and the denominator (the bottom number) by the same value until they can no longer be divided into a whole number. 

Thank you for watching our Simplest Form Song: Simplifying Fractions and learning with us.

videos.title: Coordinate Plane Song | The 6th Grade Graphing Video That Spits Actual Fire
videos.description:
Our mission? Make math fun, engaging, and oh-so-easy for both you & your students.  Our library of lesson materials is not only super-affordable but is also FREE to try out at http://numberock.com/letsrockmath.

Video History Lesson:
Nothing says “adventure” like plotting points on a graph.  Well, at least when there is treasure on the line,  it's actually not so bad.  At least that is what our two friends, Jamal and Lily, found out in the video you're watching now.

So basically this whole thing started when Lily was like “Well, we are stuck on this deserted island and don't even know how we got here, let’s try and follow these coordinates!” And Jamal sarcastically quipped, “Great, just what I wanted to do with my day off—math homework."  Lily was like, "Jamal. Hold up.  It's a lot better than dying here on this deserted beach without any good reading material like retired issues of Super Lady magazine to keep us entertained." Jamal, being an avid reader of dated back-issues of Super Lazy magazine was thus convinced that Lily was right.  Her reasoning was tighter than a squirrel's grip on a stolen acorn. Enough, said,  Jamal though, It was coordinate plane time, baby. Do or die!

The two traipsed off into the heart of the jungle, swatting mosquitoes, and finally stumbled into this cave-like underground thing with fangs bore at the entrance.  It would have been terrifying if Lily and Jamal weren't such historical enthusiasts of macabre elements of style. Classic vampire vibes. Nice touch, nature.  

But the smell inside was another story altogether.  It was something almost impossible to describe.  They couldn't quite place what it smelled like, but explorers of the ancient past have recorded that it smelled like American Cheese cooked slowly melting away on a sun-beaten truck tire - which to me just sounds like the way your average cave is gonna smell.  But hey, at least they had torches! 

Anyway, that was pretty much the whole story other than them uncovering an ancient treasure that had been buried for thousands of years but still inexplicably contained smartphones from 1997 and a bunch of Super Lady magazines.  It was really anticlimactic, to be honest.  Actually, wait, that's not exactly the whole story.  My main point is that everybody learned a ton about ordered pairs and how to graph coordinate points with both positive and negative numbers.  

Jamal went on to design video game worlds armed with his newfound knowledge of graphing and Lily retired at age 13 because there was a super-rare Super Lady magazine edition that was worth over a million dollars.  

Believe it or not, she didn't even sell it. She'd just rent it out for $2,000 a month to Instagrammers who thought it would make them look cool.  Now that's smart!

Thank you for watching our Coordinate Plane Song and learning with us.  See you in the next video!

videos.title: Place Value Song For Kids | Ones, Tens, & Hundreds | 1st - 3rd Grade
videos.description:
If you liked the video, you'll love our other fun worksheets, activities, and quizzes that go along with the video at https://learnmore.numberock.com/free-pv/.

Q.Why is it important that students learn about Place Value?
A. Learning about Place Value helps us understanding the meaning of each digit in a multi-digit number. Being able to bundle up 10 ones, because of the luxury of a tens place, allows us to express numbers like 10 and above efficiently without having to create a new digit for each number. Simply stated, place value helps us make sense of increasingly large (and small) numbers while saving time and energy communicating these values to one another.

Can you imagine having to use 100 different symbols to express values from one to one-hundred? Can you imagine not having an easy way of telling if somebody just gave you $500 or $5,000? Without the current base-10 place value system, our modern lives would be most confusing to say the least!

Q. What grade levels does this video target?
A. Kindergarten, 1st, 2nd & 3rd Grade | KS1

Q. Where did you guys come from?
A. Numberock is a project that I, Mr. Hehn, began as a 5th Grade math teacher of 7 years. It came together after years of experimenting with my lessons trying to figure out the best way to help my students retain the math concepts they were learning.

Q. Does Numberock drive real results in the classroom?
A. I knew I found the secret sauce when not only were my students retaining the concepts longer, they were singing the songs outside of the classroom during recess and at home with their parents during dinnertime. The songs were so catchy, my students couldn't get the math songs out of their head!

During testing, I often found my students humming the melodies in order to jostle their memory of a rule or problem solving process. As we've all experienced, there is something about the power of music that allows us to retain information easier and for longer periods of time. Without getting into the finer details of multi-sensory learning and how it often helps the students who most need the help, the power of a catchy song is hard to deny.

Q. I love your songs. Where can I experience more of what NUMBEROCK has to offer?
We have a fun variety of Place Value Song-themed teaching resources. Learn more at https://learnmore.numberock.com/pv/.

Learning Standards Alignment:
Common Core:
1.NBT.B.2 | 1.NBT.2
Understand that the two digits of a two-digit number represent amounts of tens and ones. Understand the following as special cases:
2.NBT.A.1 | 2.NBT.1
Understand that the three digits of a three-digit number represent amounts of hundreds, tens, and ones; e.g., 706 equals 7 hundreds, 0 tens, and 6 ones. Understand the following as special cases...
4.NBT.A.1 | 4.NBT.1
Recognize that in a multi-digit whole number, a digit in one place represents ten times what it represents in the place to its right. For example, recognize that 700 ÷ 70 = 10 by applying concepts of place value and division.

TEKS | Texas:
1.2E
Use place value to compare whole numbers up to 120 using comparative language.
2.2A
The student is expected to ruse concrete and pictorial models to compose and decompose numbers up to 1,200 in more than one way as a sum of so many thousands, hundreds, tens, and ones.
3.2B
The student is expected to describe the mathematical relationships found in the base-10 place value system through the hundred thousands place.

videos.title: 9 Times Tables Song For Kids | Multiply and Skip Count by 9
videos.description:
Our mission? Make math fun, engaging, and oh-so-easy for both you & your students.  Our library of lesson materials is not only super-affordable but is also FREE to try out at http://numberock.com/letsrockmath.

Video Summary:
You've made even though you probably never were sure that you had been invited! Actually, you definitely weren't invited, but we're still so happy to have you join us.  

So now you find yourself at time-traveling dinner party!🎉 But where exactly are you? You're at the end of a quiet country road in New York set way back in 1925. There's plenty to see here, decorative lights, cobblestone paths, and maybe even Jay Gatsby himself. 

But what’s the theme of this party? Drumroll, please… multiples of nine! We'll be counting:

Number Shaped Balloons: Up in the sky, colorful balloons float like giant jellybeans. Each balloon represents a group of nine. 

Fireflies: These little bugs are like living lanterns. They blink on and off, creating a secret code. And guess what? Their dance moves follow the same pattern as the balloons! They go 9, 18, 27, just like our friends in the sky.

Decorative Lights: Picture twinkling fairy lights strung up in front of a mansion. They’re like tiny stars that guide us. And guess what? Yep, they’re grouped in nines too! They light up in a magical sequence: 9, 18, 27, and beyond.

Now, why is all this important? Well, it helps us understand something called multiplication. When we multiply, we’re basically adding groups of the same number. So when we say “9 times 2,” we’re really saying “two groups of 9.” That’s 18! 🎈

And here’s the best part: We’re not just learning math; we’re dancing through time! So put on your imaginary dancing shoes, my friend, and let’s waltz with the nines. 🕺💫

Thank you for watching our 9 Times Tables Song and learning with us.

videos.title: Comparing Decimals | Less Than and Greater Than Decimals | Grades 4-6
videos.description:
Our mission? Make math fun, engaging, and oh-so-easy for both you & your students.  Our library of lesson materials is not only super-affordable but is also FREE to try out at http://numberock.com/letsrockmath.

 »»-------------¤-------------««»»-------------¤-------------««

Q. Why is it important for me to learn how to compare and/or order decimals?
A. If you've ever gone to a store and see a list of prices for competing products, it will be really hard to make a judgement call if you can't tell which price is the cheapest.  

If you're a football scout comparing the time of the best athletes, you'll want to instantly be able to compare 40 yard dash times as the players complete their combine.  These times are almost always expressed to the nearest 100th of a second, in order to put together a full profile of the player you are scouting. 

To effectively take part in our economy, it's also necessary to be able to understand fractional parts of %'s of ownership, often expressed in decimals, when it comes to understanding how much of a company you own.   

Did you know just .001% of Apple Computers is worth about $10,000,000?  Decimal places can sure make a lot of cents!  The examples of understanding decimals values in the real world are almost endless!

Q. What grade levels do this video target?
A. 4th Grade & 5th Grade.  However reinforcement of this concept may continue all the way up until 6th grade.   

 »»-------------¤-------------««»»-------------¤-------------««

videos.description:

videos.title: Thanksgiving Song for Kids | The Pilgrims Journey To the New World
videos.description:
Video: The First Thanksgiving Day Song
Grade Levels: Kids in All Grades
🍎  Check out our ever-growing library of math songs at https://www.numberock.com. 🍎

SUMMARY:
The Pilgrims leave Holland after fleeing from England where they were persecuted because of their faith.  After an arduous oversea journey, they land at Piymouth Rock where they make contact with the Wampanoag Indians.  There they meet great Indians of the past like Samoset, Massasoit, and Squanto.  After establishing good relations with the Indians, they agree to feast together and enjoy the bounty of the crop following a devastating winter in the new land.

videos.title: Counting to 10 in Song For Preschool-Kindergarten
videos.description:
Kindergarten and preschool teachers, explore Numberock’s equally fun teaching resources with a free month of access available for a limited time at http://numberock.com/letsrockmath.

Created for Pre-K to Kindergarten learners, this song teaches counting to 10 by showing dogs, koala bears, penguins, monkeys, cats, and ten kindergartners - all drawn in the cutest possible way. 

LYRICS:
One, two , three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten…
Dogs are barking over and over again.
Koala bears are roaring over and over again.
Penguins are calling over and over again.
Monkeys are hooting over and over again.
Cat's are meowing over and over again.
Children are cheering in kindergarten.

Target Audience:
Preschool to Kindergarten or English Language Learners

This video addresses the following Common Core Standards:
K.CC.A.2 - Count forward beginning from a given number within the known sequence (instead of having to begin at 1).
K.CC.A.3 - Write numbers from 0 to 20. Represent a number of objects with a written numeral 0-20 (with 0 representing a count of no objects).
K.CC.B.4 - Count to tell the number of objects.
K.CC.B.4b - Understand that the last number name said tells the number of objects counted. The number of objects is the same regardless of their arrangement or the order in which they were counted.

heh heh, then perhaps look somewhere else?

I love you a ton.
You mean a great dill to me.

Owl be yours...
will ewe be mine?

heh heh, well don’t ask us two;
but here’s a few more that will dooooo.

I lava you.
It’s true that I’m nuts about you.

My heart beats for you.
Somebunny loves you.

If you were looking for the perfect valentine...
then I hope you don’t feel we’ve wasted your time.
You may as well give one of ours a try!

 »»-------------¤-------------««»»-------------¤-------------««

Q. I'd like to show my students this video but my school blocks YouTube videos.  Where else can I watch this video to work around this problem?
A. You can watch this video here; ad-free and child-safe:
https://numberock.com/lessons/skip_counting_by_9/

Here is a neat little trick to help you master the 9 times table. 
 »»  is 10× the number minus the number. 
Example: 9×6 = 10×6−6 = 60−6 = 54
 »»  the ones digit goes 9, 8, 7, 6, ...: 9, 18, 27, 36, 45, ...
  the tens digit goes  0, 1, 2, 3, ...: 9, 18, 27, 36, 45, ...
 »» subtract one to get the tens digit, and the tens and ones digit together make 9
Example: 9×5: tens digit is 4, 4 and 5 make 9, so 45
Example: 9×8: tens digit is 7, 7 and 2 make 9, so 72

Q. What is a symmetry?
A. Symmetry is when a shape or object has two completely identical sides that are either facing each other or are around an axis. A line of symmetry is the line that divides the two identical parts, each part being a mirror reflection of the other.

videos.description:
Check out our ever-growing library of math songs at https://www.numberock.com.

This video will be the perfect way to introduce your class transformations. Students will learn that a flip is a reflection, a slide is a translation, and a turn is a rotation, while also reviewing the concepts of symmetry and dilations, which are used to complete enlargements and reductions of shapes using a fixed center point and a ration called a scale factor. 

Q. What grade levels do this video target?
A. This video targets learning standards in 8th Grade.  

Our Transformations song and video is aligned with the following Common Core standards:
CCSS 8.G.1
Verify experimentally the properties of rotations, reflections, and translations
CCSS 8.G.3
Describe the effect of dilations, translations, rotations, and reflections on two-dimensional figures using coordinates.

videos.title: I Can Show Numbers in Different Ways Song | Representing Numbers | Kindergarten
videos.description:
Kindergarten teachers, explore Numberock’s equally fun teaching resources with a free month of access available for a limited time at http://numberock.com/letsrockmath

Thank you for watching our song about showing numbers in different ways. 

The NUMBEROCK Bluegrass Band is back with Suzy and friends as they learn about numerals, counting objects, five frames, ten frames, tally marks, and all the other number types we see in our daily lives... like in playing games with dice or dominoes, keeping track of the days, planting a garden, or even planning a road trip. We welcome you to sing along with us if you agree that "Counting numbers can be so much fun! Numbers are for Everyone!!"

This video covers math standards in Kindergarten, 1st Grade, and 2nd Grade.

Learning Goals:
I can show and represent numbers in different ways.
I can count the numbers 1-10 using my 10 fingers.
I can communicate a number as a standard numeral or through its written word equivalent.
I can compose numbers using tally marks, five frames, ten frames and base ten blocks.
I can showcase a number using a number line, or by representing the amount using pictures.
I can use play items like dice and dominoes to learn how to subitize (the act of instantly recognizing a group of objects without having to count the individual objects).

videos.title: Unidades, Decenas, y Centenas Para Niños | Canción de Valor Posicional
videos.description:
Visite numberock.com para obtener materiales didácticos y más:
https://numberock.com/lessons/valor-posicional-place-value-spanish-version/

Lección: Valor Posicional | Place Value in Spanish for Kids
Gracias por aprender sobre unidades, decenas y centenas con Numberock.

Letra:
La canción del valor posicional
Cogiendo peras, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9;
eso es todo lo que cabe en las unidades.
Tomé otra más y formé un grupo de diez.
Eso hizo una decena exactamente.
20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, 90:
Seguí recolectando con el hambre que me tienta.
Entonces tomé una decena más
y eso formó una centena.
(Con una pera me golpeé y canté ...)

Diez unidades son diez.
Diez decenas forman cien.
Diez centenas son mil;
El patrón no tiene fin.

Monté un kilómetro mi bici
y 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9 más hice.
Un kilómetro más hizo un grupo de diez.
Una voz en mi cabeza dijo:
"¡Tú puedes! ¿no lo ves?”
20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, 90:
¡No sabía que podía llevar tan larga cuenta!
El final del recorrido estaba por llegar.
Llegué a la centena sólo con diez más.
(Y la voz quiso cantar ...)

Diez unidades son diez.
Diez decenas forman cien.
Diez centenas son mil;
El patrón no tiene fin.

Cuando dieron las ocho en el salón de clases,
empecé a jugar con mis bloques multibase.
Apilé nueve y luego uno más son diez,
y luego diez decenas equivalen cien.
200, 300, 400, 500, 600, 700, 800, 900:
En las centenas otro cien más no logré poner.
En la unidad de mil tendría que caber.
(luego mi bajo toqué).

Diez unidades son diez.
Diez decenas forman cien.
Diez centenas son mil;
El patrón no tiene fin.

Diez grupos de mil son decena de mil.
Diez diez mil, una centena de mil.
Diez de aquellas forman un millón.
Y el patrón no tiene fin.

videos.title: Introduction to Algebra Song | Variables & Algebraic Expressions
videos.description:
We hope you enjoyed the mathematical rhymes in our Introduction to Algebra Rap Song.  Discover more ad-free videos and fun video-aligned lesson extenders at https://numberock.com.

About the Song:
This song helps students master important 7th Grade math standards by introducing the concept of letters in algebraic expressions, ie Algebra.  Students during their elementary education most often deal in expressions that have specific numeric values, but as they develop their mathematical skills beyond elementary, they'll soon discover that many expressions and equations have letters called variables in place of a specific number. 

These letters stand in for an unknown numeric value that and represent a range of potential values.  Since these values are unknown, mathematicians have decided that letters, like "x" and "y" for example, make great substitutes for numbers when we have incomplete information.

Additionally, students watching the song will be taught how to identify parts of expressions with mathematical terms.  Some of these terms are sums, products, factors, quotients, coefficients and more.

videos.title: Fracciones en la recta numérica para niños | Canción de primaria
videos.description:
Obtener una prueba gratuita en www.numberock.com

Cancion de ubicar fracciones en recta numérica:
Únete a Benny en su escuela donde está investigando fracciones en rectas numéricas. Recibe ayuda de su amiga Thania y luego le muestra a su animal de peluche cómo escribir 1/3 en la recta numérica. Mientras hace su tarea más tarde en la noche, Benny se atasca en un problema sobre trazar una fracción en una recta numérica que es mayor que uno, por lo que le envía un mensaje de texto a Thania para obtener ayuda.

Letras:
Le pregunté a mi mejor amiga Érica
Dónde va un medio en la recta numérica.
Ella dijo: "Primero dibuja la recta".
Luego me cantó una canción perfecta.

De cero a uno es el todo que se dividirá.
El denominador dice en cuántas partes lo hará.
Salta desde cero hasta la primera marca,
Y un medio es lo que encuentras cuando llegas allá.

Mi peluche no habla, pero lo oí preguntar:
"Oye, Ben, en la recta, ¿un tercio dónde va?"
Yo le dije: “Primero, dibuja la recta.
Luego canta conmigo esta canción perfecta”.

De cero a uno es el todo que se dividirá.
El denominador dice en cuántas partes lo hará.
Salta desde cero hasta la primera marca,
Y un tercio es lo que encuentras cuando llegas allá.

“¿Qué se hace -pregunté con fervor-
si no es uno el numerador?"
Dijo: "tratemos de buscar cinco novenos
en la recta numérica lo hallaremos.
Primero dividamos en nueve nuestro entero
Luego da cinco saltos y a cinco novenos llegaremos".

De cero a uno es el todo que se dividirá.
El denominador dice en cuántas partes lo hará.
Salta desde cero hasta la quinta marca,
Y a cinco novenos lograrás llegar.

Usemos la recta para hablar del pastel.
Contemos las cinco rebanadas en él.
Cinco son las partes, el denominador, por lo que cinco va debajo en la fracción.
Esta recta va desde el cero al dos,
Pero la fracción es menor que uno.
Crea cinco espacios desde cero al uno.
Ahora, el último paso y así no me abrumo
El numerador uno es mi rebanada.
Escribo un quinto bajo la primera marca.
Recuerda este consejo, hazlo muy despacio.
Y no cuentes las líneas, sino los espacios.

De cero a uno es el todo que se dividirá.
El denominador dice en cuántas partes lo hará.
Salta desde cero hasta la primera marca,
Y un quinto es lo que encuentras cuando llegas allá.

Gracias por aprender sobre fracciones en una recta numérica con nosotros.  
Espero que puedas unirte a nosotros en el próximo video!
Muchas Gracias,
Numberock

videos.title: Place Value Song For Kids | Up To The Millions | 3rd - 5th Grade
videos.description:
3rd and 4th Grade teachers, explore Numberock’s equally fun teaching resources with a free month of access available for a limited time at http://numberock.com/letsrockmath

Q.Why is it important that students learn about Place Value?
A. Learning about Place Value helps us understanding the meaning of each digit in a multi-digit number. Being able to bundle up 10 ones, because of the luxury of a tens place, allows us to express numbers like 10 and above efficiently without having to create a new digit for each number. Simply stated, place value helps us make sense of increasingly large (and small) numbers while saving time and energy communicating these values to one another.

Can you imagine having to use 100 different symbols to express values from one to one-hundred? Can you imagine not having an easy way of telling of somebody just gave you $500 or $5,000? Without the current base-10 place value system, our modern lives would be most confusing to say the least!

Q. What grade levels does this video target?
A. 3rd, 4th, and 5th grade | year 3, year 4

Q. Where did you guys come from?
A. Numberock is a project that I, Mr. Hehn, began as a 5th Grade math teacher of 7 years. It came together after years of experimenting with my lessons trying to figure out the best way to help my students retain the math concepts they were learning.

Q. Does Numberock drive real results in the classroom?
A. I knew I found the secret sauce when not only were my students retaining the concepts longer, they were singing the songs outside of the classroom during recess and at home with their parents during dinnertime. The songs were so catchy, my students couldn't get the math songs out of their head!

During testing, I often found my students humming the melodies in order to jostle their memory of a rule or problem solving process. As we've all experienced, there is something about the power of music that allows us to retain information easier and for longer periods of time. Without getting into the finer details of multi-sensory learning and how it often helps the students who most need the help, the power of a catchy song is hard to deny.

Q. I love your songs. Where can I experience more of what NUMBEROCK has to offer?
We have a fun variety of Place Value Song-themed teaching resources. Learn more at

Simply stated, place value helps us make sense of increasingly large (and small) numbers while saving time and energy communicating these values to one another.

Can you imagine having to use 100 different symbols to express values from one to one-hundred? Can you imagine not having an easy way of telling of somebody just gave you $500 or $5,000? Without the current base-10 place value system, our modern lives would be most confusing to say the least!

Q. What grade levels does this video target?
A. 3rd, 4th, and 5th grade | year 3, year 4

Q. Where did you guys come from?
A. Numberock is a project that I, Mr. Hehn, began as a 5th Grade math teacher of 7 years. It came together after years of experimenting with my lessons trying to figure out the best way to help my students retain the math concepts they were learning.

Q. Does Numberock drive real results in the classroom?
A. I knew I found the secret sauce when not only were my students retaining the concepts longer, they were singing the songs outside of the classroom during recess and at home with their parents during dinnertime. The songs were so catchy, my students couldn't get the math songs out of their head!

During testing, I often found my students humming the melodies in order to jostle their memory of a rule or problem solving process. As we've all experienced, there is something about the power of music that allows us to retain information easier and for longer periods of time. Without getting into the finer details of multi-sensory learning and how it often helps the students who most need the help, the power of a catchy song is hard to deny.

videos.title: Largo y corto para niños | Canciones infantiles | Comparación de medidas
videos.description:
Visite numberock.com para obtener materiales didácticos y mucho más:
https://learnmore.numberock.com/GratisS5

Acerca de esta canción:
¡Los estudiantes de jardín de infancia y 1er grado están de acuerdo! Comparar longitudes y medidas nunca ha sido tan divertido como lo han hecho Tico y Mario en esta canción ridículamente divertida de los monos muy bien pagados de Numberock. Como pronto descubrirás, Mario generalmente tiene objetos que son un poco más largos que los objetos de Tico, pero como muestra Tico, ¡las habilidades con la guitarra no dependen de qué tan corta o larga sea la guitarra!

Letra
El cordón de Tico mide dos pies,
El cordón de Mario mide cuatro pies.
Mario le dijo a Tico
Mi cordón esta vez es más largo,
El tuyo dos pies, el mío cuatro.
De dos pies más largo es mi cordón.

¡Digo HEYO!
¿Quién tiene más largo el cordón?
¡Digo HEYO!
Mario tiene el más largo cordón.

El bote de Mario mide nueves pies,
El bote de Tico mide cinco pies,
Tico le dijo a Mario
Mi botecito es más corto,
El tuyo es nueve, el mío cinco es.
El mío es más corto por cuatro pies.

¡Digo HEYO!
¿Quién tiene el bote más corto?
¡Digo HEYO!
Tico tiene el bote más corto.

El telescopio de Tico mide tres pies.
El telescopio de Mario mide cinco pies.
Mario le dijo a Tico
Tengo un telescopio más largo,
Porque el mío mide cinco y el tuyo tres.
Así que el mío es más largo por dos pies.

¡Digo HEYO!
¿Quién tiene el telescopio más largo?
¡Digo HEYO!
El telescopio de Mario es más largo.

¡Digo HEYO!
¿Cuál instrumento es más largo?

Tico y Mario combinarán
En la recta numérica sus frutas.
La de Mario mide once pulgadas.
La de Tico mide nueve pulgadas.
Desde once sumaron nueve más.
Veinte pulgadas para cenar.

Gracias por ver nuestra canción más grande y más corta y tomarse el tiempo para aprender con nosotros.

videos.title: Counting From 1-5 Song | Dogs & Cats  | Preschool
videos.description:
Our mission? Make math fun, engaging, and oh-so-easy for both you & your students.  Try our program free for a month at http://numberock.com/letsrockmath.

Join us in the front yard on Fairview Ln. where an adorable pack of cute little dogs are getting together for the expressed purpose of letting you count them from one to five! Then the cats try to outdo them! Did they fail? You decide.

After watching this video, if you can fluently count to five, we think you ready for our next video on Advanced Calculus.  It's the next logical step-up.

Thanks for learning with us.  We hope you found the song useful, engaging. and melodic.

videos.title: Angles Song II | How to Measure Angles With A Protractor | Featuring Earl
videos.description:
Earl is back and this time he's got protractors, lots of 'em.  He has an urgent message the public needs to be aware of, and it has to do with drawing and measuring angles, or as he calls it, "degrees extraction". 

In order to fully commit to the lesson, Earl's taken a day off from delivering pizza. We'll find him sippin' on organic apple juice boxes with his friend Jay.  They gaze at the clock, but not to tell what time it is. Rather, their focus remains solely on the two hands of the clock which form a 99 degree angle. Earl and his good friend then celebrate their love of protractors which inspired a secret handshake, a symbol of a bond that no-one can break.  

Also, the moose from the original Angles video makes a reappearance, but if you watch all the way to the very end, you may be just as confused as we are about if the moose is actually making a reappearance, or if appearances aren't always exactly what they seem.

So wait, has this whole angles video series been some sort of moosed-out fever dream?  Honestly, we have no idea.  That's for you, and you alone, to decide.  

If you remember, in the last video, we posed the question, "Which angle looks like the antlers on the head of a full-grown moose?"  In this video, we ask if our whole universe comes into and out of existence with each resting breath of the Numberock moose.  Our guess?  Probably.

videos.title: Counting 1-10 Song | Pre-K to Kindergarten
videos.description:
Our mission? Make math fun, engaging, and oh-so-easy for both you and your students. Our library of lesson materials is not only super affordable but also FREE to try at numberock.com/letsrockmath.

Video: Count to 10 Number Song for Kids 
Grade Levels: Pre-K to Kindergarten

Join Lindsey and her cousin Benji as they go on a picnic and meet a variety of animals, each representing a different number from 1 to 10. From puppies riding excavators to dancing ducks, they count along, discovering how many animals they can find. The journey is filled with catchy melodies, fun visuals, and opportunities for kids to sing and count along as they explore numbers 1-10 with their new animal friends!

Q. What grade levels does this video target?
A. This video is designed for Pre-K, Kindergarten, and 1st Grade learning standards.

Q. Where did Numberock come from?
A. Numberock is a project that I, Mr. Hehn, started as a 5th Grade math teacher after 7 years in the classroom. It was born out of my desire to create engaging ways for my students to retain and enjoy math.

Q. Does Numberock drive real results in the classroom?
A. Absolutely! My students began retaining math concepts more effectively, singing the songs outside of the classroom during recess, and even teaching the songs to their families at home. Music became their secret tool for memory recall, especially during testing.

There’s something undeniable about the power of music—it sticks in your head, and when used to teach math, it helps students grasp and retain concepts in a fun and engaging way. And this method works particularly well for students who might struggle with traditional learning tools.

Q. I love your songs! Where can I find more from Numberock?

A. Check out all that NUMBEROCK has to offer on our website at numberock.com. You can explore our complete library of learning resources for free for an entire month! After your free month, you can lock in a subscription for just $4.95/month or $49.95/year to continue accessing our amazing content.

videos.title: Circumference Song | Circumference of a Circle
videos.description:
Join us at Numberock.com and get your free trial today: https://numberock.com/letsrockmath/

Get ready for a tree-mendous journey with our " Circumference Song"! Head out on a heartfelt quest as Ellis shows us his love for nature and trees by learning how to calculate the circumference of a circle! When his favorite tree is cut down, he honors it by making a wreath and a gold ring. But to do so, he needs to understand the circumference and diameter of the tree to properly pay tribute. As you follow his story, maybe... just maaaybe... you too will discover that sometimes math is more than just numbers... it's a way to show trees you care.

This educational song is perfect for 5th and 6th graders learning circle math, including how to use the formula for circumference: C = πd. Students will explore geometry in a meaningful way as the man learns how to calculate the diameter and radius to preserve the memory of his tree.

This video is great for:

    Learning circumference for 5th grade math
    Understanding circle measurements in 6th grade math
    Finding out how to calculate circumference with C=πd

Perfect for classrooms, homeschoolers, or any student who wants to get to the "root" of circumference in a fun way.

videos.title: Multiplying by Multiples of 10 Song | 3rd Grade Multiplication
videos.description:

This catchy math song that helps students master multiplying by multiples of 10—a foundational concept aligned with 3rd grade math standards including Common Core 3.NBT.3, Florida B.E.S.T. MA.3.NSO.2.4, and Texas TEKS 3.4B. Through lively verses and a fun chorus, learners explore how to use place value and properties of operations to multiply one-digit numbers by 10, 20, 30, and more. Whether you’re a teacher, parent, or student, this engaging resource reinforces strategies for multiplication while meeting essential requirements in multiple states. Sing along as we “look at the fact in the tens place—solve it in isolation, then write the zero back after your calculation,” and watch your multiplication skills soar!

videos.title: 2-Digit by 1-Digit Multiplication Song w/ Partial Products
videos.description:
Join us at Numberock.com and get your free trial today: https://numberock.com/letsrockmath/

Master 2-digit by 1-digit multiplication with this fun, engaging math music video! Perfect for 3rd and 4th graders, this lesson focuses on the partial products method and aligns with TEKS 3.4G and CCSS 4.NBT.B.5. Watch as we explore real-world multiplication word problems, using visual models, place value strategies, and step-by-step demos to build strong number sense skills.

In this video, we’ll break down the process of multiplying a two-digit number by a one-digit number, highlighting how to decompose numbers into tens and ones for clear, easy calculations. Discover how partial products come together to form the total product, and learn to check your work for accuracy. Whether you’re a teacher in search of standards-aligned content, a homeschool parent, or a student eager for fun math practice, this video provides a clear approach to mastering multi-digit multiplication.

Topics Covered:
• Partial products & place value
• 2-digit by 1-digit multiplication demos
• Common Core & TEKS alignment
• Engaging, real-life word problems

Don’t forget to like, share, and subscribe to stay updated on more Numberock videos designed to make math concepts easy and enjoyable!

videos.title: Earth Day Rap | Reduce, Reuse, Recycle | Educational Song
videos.description:
This Earth Day rap song focuses on educating students on protecting our planet, Earth, emphasizing that it’s our only home. The song covers "The Three R's"; reducing, reusing and recycling.

It suggests practical steps like recycling cans and bottles by sorting them properly and reducing paper use to limit pollution. Opting to walk or bike instead of drive helps lower emissions, while combining errands into one trip conserves fuel. Small actions—such as conserving water, switching to LED lights, or composting—can have a big impact on reducing waste and energy use. The song calls for collective effort, urging us to consider future generations and embrace reducing, reusing, and recycling to ensure Earth’s well-being.
